loans.use: To buy glass and paint

loans.name: Oung

texts.en:
Oung K. is a 38-year-old lady who lives with her family in the Moulkorl Borey village in Banteay Meanchey. She is an internal officer for a private company. She has been working in this sector since 1999, and earns an average of $5 per day. 

Recently, to harvest her rice crops, she had hired a few domestic laborers.  Now it is the time to pay them.  However, her savings are not enough to pay this cost in full.  Oung K. is asking for a loan to supplement her personal savings to pay for this harvesting cost.

loans.use: To pay for harvesting cost

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao S. is a hard-working woman who spent most of her life farming. She has a life partner in her husband, who helps her in the farm field. This couple earns an income of around $6 a day to support the expenses for the whole family. They have two children, both are employed as workers in a factory in Kompong Tom Province. 

Presently, Sao S. would like to do dry-season rice farming, but she does not have enough capital.  Sao S. is asking for a loan to buy a pumping machine, seeds, and fertilizers.

loans.use: To buy pump, seeds, and fertilizers.

loans.name: Tiaulel Ene Lloitei

texts.en:
Tiaulel Ene Loitei K. is 42 Years old, married and a mother of eight children. Tiaulel is a farmer and she does the farming on her own piece of land which she has been doing for the last nine years.

She learned about KADET LTD from other women in a group already registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be her second loan after she successfuly paid the first loan well and in time. She is planning to buy fertilizer, wheat and maize seeds for planting season.  

Tiaulel Ene  hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to build a permanent house. She hopes to be a prominent farmer of wheat and better living of the family. She is an industrious woman who is determined to achieve her set objectives.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and wheat and maize seeds.

loans.name: Elena's Group

texts.en:
Elena M. is from the village of Baculud Amulung, Cagayan. She is 56 years old. Elena is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Elena M.'s Group.

Elena is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business providing passenger van services. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase an additional vehicle for the business. 

Elena is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Elena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair vehicle for better service

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is 32 years old and the mother of two.  She runs a small store called Midside Shop so as to earn a living.  She also sells charcoal and rents out houses.  She has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to build more rental houses.

As a business-lady, she faces a lot of competition, but she works hard to provide the best quality products to her customers.  In future she aspires to open a supermarket, and also dreams of buying a piece of land.

loans.use: To build more rental houses

loans.name: Arise Club-Mpigi Group

texts.en: 30 year old K. Abdul has been in the motorcycle transportation business for the past 8 years in Kayabwe-Mpigi. Abdul also does poultry farming. He says he began his motorcycle business soon after the completion of school. Before, he took root in this business, he was more inclined to buying and selling agro produce. Weekly this business generates him shillings 70,000 and he says with this loan, he is going to buy more chicken mash for his poultry. Abdul belongs to Arise club-Mpigi.

loans.use: The purchase of more chicken mash for his poultry

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Vann P. is a 43-year-old married woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Tom Province. She and her husband have six children; five are single and one is married. 

Vann P. has a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She grows rice on her land, and she can plant twice per year, once in the dry season and once in the rainy season.  She has other financial support from her husband who works as a soldier in Dongkor village.  Vann P. is requesting this loan to buy an ox, because the ox she has now is old and doesn't pull the plow well any more while doing field work.

loans.use: To buy an ox

loans.name: Tobias

texts.en: Tobias is a businessman and a member of the Jitihada group in Faulu Kenya.  He sells ladies' clothes in the Kibera slums.  He has been in the business for four years.  He has managed to educate his four children with the income from his business and the funding from Faulu Kenya.  He dreams of opening a wholesale business in the future.  He has requested 40,000 KES to buy more clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Jannette's Group

texts.en:
Jannette B. is from the village of Gosi Sur. She is 47 years old and the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jannette B.'s Group.

Jannette is married. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately $94 a month for these activities.

In 2010, she joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering.

Jannette is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as savings for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Pho

texts.en: The man shown in the picture is Mr. Pho S., 21, a fisherman. He usually needs to take eight hours a day to fish around the river in the village. He catches around five kilos of fish per day and sells them in bulk to his customers who are retail sellers. His wife’s name is Thy; she is 16 years old and works in the farming business. The young couple is blessed with one young child who is still not enrolled in school. Mr. Pho S. will use his loan to buy a used motorbike for transporting his fish for sale.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for transporting his fish for sale.

loans.name: Khankishi

texts.ru:
Khankishi R. 31 qoda. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey , starshiy iz detey uchitsya v 5 klasse a mladshiy v 3 klasse. Khankishi yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione
 vmeste so svoyey jenoy i lubimimi detmi. 
Khankishi uje 5 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom, on v svoyom obyekte  zanimayetsya pochinkoy isporchennix telefonov i v toje vremya prodayet nujniye zapchasti, shnuri dlya telefonov. Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo starsheqo brata, on nauchil yeqo bit xoroshim masterom i lubit svoyu rabotu. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit nujniye tovar( telefonniye shnuri zapchasti a takje , chexli dlya telefonov).
texts.en:
Khankishi R. is thirty-one and married with two children.  The eldest is in 5th grade and the youngest in 3rd grade.  Khankishi is an IDP [Internally Displaced Person], from the city of Fuzili and he now lives in the Fuzili region with his wife and beloved children.

Khankishi has been in business now for five years fixing broken telephones in his own shop, and selling phone parts and cables.  He learned the business from his older brother, who taught him how to be proficient and to love his work.  Khankishi needs 2000 AZN to buy merchandise (telephone cables, cell phone cases and parts).

loans.use: He would like to buy merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is a talented lady who owns and operates an embroidery business to financially assist her husband. She is very good at her work and receives regular orders from her neighboring clients. The income she earns from her business helps her pay the utility bills. Her husband’s name is Z. H., and he operates a fruit selling business. They both get up early in the morning and start doing their work. 

Razia is the mother of six children. All of them are studying except the youngest daughter, who is only one year old. She lives in an industrial city of Pakistan called Gujranwala. For the past thirteen years she has lived with her family in a three-room brick house in the area named Kalar abadiy.  

She has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy seasonal fruits and also a new four-wheeled cart for his business. His old cart has become rough and rotten in different areas. He has been operating this business for the past ten years, and Razia is hopeful that an investment will help him improve his business. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah.
  
Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called the Asasah Passbook) is Razia.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits and a four-wheeled cart

loans.name: Nkoriais Ole Mankura

texts.en:
Nkoriais Ole Mankura K. is 38 years old .He is married and a father of fifteen children. Nkoriais is a farmer and he has been doing this for the last four years. His farm is in a productive area which has proved to be good for wheat farming.

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign done by KADET staffs in his area of residence. This will be his first loan which he is planning to prepare his wheat farming which normally do well in his area due to good climatic conditions. 

He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to increase his wheat production and educate his children. In future he desires to practice large scale farming. Nkoriais is a hard working man who can do more if supported financially

loans.use: to prepare his wheat farm which normally do well in his area due to good climatic conditions.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch Y. has spent her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. She is now married and has five kids, three of whom are married while the others are single. Two of them are working in various jobs and have a regular salary every month. 

Frequently her husband works in the farm fields alongside her. Growing crops is an annual action with which she has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. 

This is the time for preparing dry-season rice fields, but Touch Y. doesn’t have enough capital yet to use on her farm. She is asking for a loan to use for hiring a plow for her farmland and to purchase fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.use: To hire a plow and purchase fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Neema Group

texts.fr: Kyakimwa S.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe Neema, âgée de 52 ans, mariée, mère de 6 enfants.  Son conjoint est un fonctionnaire de l’Etat à l’office congolais de contrôle (OCC),l’ une des grandes entreprises publiques en RDCongo. Elle fait le petit commerce de vente de  Fanta (sucrés) à son domicile. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre par une activité de vente de pagnes. Plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ en 2004. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux produits (40 casiers de Fanta sucrés) pour augmenter son stock en volume et en valeurs.  En plus, elle ambitionne ouvrier une boutique de référence. La cliente Kyakimwa S.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Neema est constitué de 14 membres.
texts.en:
Kyakimwa S. is an entrepreneure and president of the Neema solidarity group, which is composed of 14 members. She is 52 years old and married with six children. Her husband is an official with the Congolese control office, one of DRC’s largest public corporations.  

She sells Fanta (soft drink) from her home. She started her business using her own capital to sell pagnes (colorful West-African cloth). Later, in 2004, she obtained a $50 loan from the Hekima MFI. 

This new loan will be used to buy merchandise (40 cases of Fanta soft drink) to increase her stock both in volume and in value. She also plans to open a reference shop. 

Kyakimwa S. wishes to thank Hekima for helping the less fortunate who don’t have the option of turning to traditional banks.

loans.use: Buying 40 cases of Fanta soft drink

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Naisianta Ene

texts.en:
Naisianta Ene K. is 42 Years old, married and a mother of seven and surports ten other people.She does farming activity on her own piece of land for the last twelve years.

She learnt about KADET LTD from other women in a group already registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be her second loan which she is planning to spend to buy fertilizer and three bags of wheat and maize seeds. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Naisianta dream is do buy a good house and settle her family. She is an assiduous woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and three bags of wheat and maize seeds for planting

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Yim D. is an older woman. She is a local rice farmer who has been working in this sector since her children were very young. Currently, she owns a piece of land on which she cultivates different kinds of crops to earn a living. She has a life partner in her husband who works as a military officer, making a profit of approximately $8 a day. They have six children, two of whom are married and live independently, while the others are single. 

Recently, the family is facing difficulty with their living conditions due to their house needing repair. To solve the problem, Yim D. would like a loan to repair a part of her broken house.

loans.use: To repair a part of her broken house.

loans.name: George Mwachala

texts.en:
George Mwachala K. is a 36 year old man. He is married to Janet and together they have four children. George has been in the transport as a primary business for the last two years. Besides transport business, he also manages a clothes material shop which is runned by the wife most of time. 

He was introduced to KADET by a friend and this is his first loan from KADET, and he plans to purchase clothing materials for sale with aim to boost the clothing material business.

The anticipated profits will be directed into the expansion of his cloth business. His dreams and hopes are to succeed through KADET.

loans.use: purchase materials into his cloth business

loans.name: Allen

texts.en: Allen is a thirty-eight-year-old married female with two children who rents a house in Kasese. She has been dealing in secondhand clothes for the last seven years. She started her business with a capital of 100,000 UGX and later increased it to 1,500,000 UGX. Her hardship is the lack of customers during the rainy season. Her vision is to start a boutique and educate her children. Allen needs the loan to buy more clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothes to resell.

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.en:
Anastasia is 40 years old married to peter Mugo who contributes to the family income. They have four children aged 16, 13,13, and four years old. Anastasia has been rearing pigs for a period of five years with an income of about KES.9,000 per month.

Anastasia has never borrowed from any other MFI, she is taking her second loan after sucessfuly repaying the previous one. She intends to use it to buy more pigs to increase her profit margin. She hopes to be a leading pig farmer and educate her children to higher education level.

loans.use: To buy more pigs

loans.name: Deus

texts.en: Deus is a forty-year-old married male with nine children who owns a house in Kasese. He has been dealing in an alcohol business for the last ten years, which he started with five jerrycans and now has thirty of them. His hardship is some customers' delay in paying him. His vision is to expand his business to two hundred jerrycans. Deus intends to use the loan to buy more jerrycans of alcohol to resell.

loans.use: To buy jerrycans of alcohol to resell

loans.name: Goretti

texts.fr: Goretti N. est commerçante, et client d’ACB depuis 2009.  Elle a 36 ans, née à Rwanda, mariée, et elle a 2 enfants entre 3 ans et 4 ans.  Elle a une éducation primaire, et tous ses enfants vont à l’école.  Elle va utiliser son prêt pout l’achat de 20 sacs de pommes de terre, et payer pour le transport.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargner, et d’autofinancement.  Elle voudrait devenir grossiste, et construire une maison d’habitation pour la famille.
texts.en: Goretti N. is a merchant and a client of ACB since 2009. She is 36 years old, she was born in Rwanda, she is married, and she has 2 children between the ages of 3 and 4. She has a primary school education, and all of her children attend school. She will use her loan to purchase 20 sacks of potatoes and to pay for the transportation. Her strategy for making her business grow is to save money and form a capital fund. She would like to become a wholesaler and to build a home for her family.

loans.use: To purchase 20 sacks of potatoes.

loans.name: Kyosimba Onanya Kibuga-Mpigi Group

texts.en: 34 year old S. Jalia is affiliated to Kyosimba onanya Kibuga group-Mpigi.  She has been running her retail shop in Mpigi town for ten years. At her shop she sells a variety of general merchandise retail commodities which are mostly of high preference to families around her operating area. Monthly this business generates her shillings 800,000. Jalia who is happily married with six kids has side coffee and ginger sells businesses. With this loan, Jalia says she is going to purchase more general merchandise retail commodities to resell at her shop.

loans.use: The purchase of more general merchandise retail commodities to resell

loans.name: Fredrick Karanja

texts.en:
Fredrick is 50 years old, married to Naomi Wanjiku who contributes to the family income. They have five children aged 18, 14, 12, 10, and nine years old. Fredrick has been growing french beens for a period of four years with an income of about KES 5,500 per month.

He has very good credit history with KADET, and this is his third loan after repaying the previous ones successfuly. He intends to use the loan to buy fertilizer and seedlings.

He hopes to expand his farming activity and support his family. He dreams to be a large scale farmer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: Odette N. est commerçante, et client d’ACB depuis 2009.  Elle est veuve, et elle a 8 enfants entre 12 ans et 29 ans.  Elle a une éducation d’école primaire, et tous ses enfants vont à l’école.  Elle va utiliser son prêt pour l’achat des 40 sacs de pommes de terre pour les détailler.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargner, et augmenter la quantité vendue.  Elle voudrait devenir fournisseur de pommes de terre, et avoir  les champs plantés.  Pour sa famille, elle voudrait éduquer les enfants, travailler sur sa maison, et, si c’est possible, construire une nouvelle maison.
texts.en: Odette N. is a merchant and a client of ACB since 2009. She is a widow and she has 8 children between the ages of 12 and 29. She has a primary school education and all of her children attend school. She would like to use her loan to purchase 40 sacks of potatoes for resale. Her strategy to make her business grow is to save money to and to increase her sales. She would like to become a supplier of potatoes and to have plantation fields. As for her family, she would like to educate her children, work at home, and if possible, to build a new house.

loans.use: To purchase 40 sacks of potatoes.

loans.name: Micheal Kamu

texts.en:
Micheal, age 61, is married to Mary Nyambura, who is a farmer.  He rears sheep for sale on his farm in Limuru. His wife is of great assistance in the farming activities. He has done this for 32 years and he is able to support his family from the proceeds and support his grandchildren as well.

This is the second loan he has received from KADET Ltd. and he intends to use it to buy a dairy cow for milk production since this will be his source of income.  This will bring him more income for the family. 

From the profits of this loan, he desires to develop a piece of land he had acquired earlier for the family.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Delina

texts.en:
Delina is 42 years old, married, and has three children. Two of her children go to school. Delina owns a carpentry business and has been working as a carpenter with her husband for twenty years.

Her loan will be used to purchase lumber and construction equipment which will be used in the business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more lumber and equipment.

loans.name: Jonna's Group

texts.en:
Jonna A. is from the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 33 years old and the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jonna is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a recycling service, hauling scrap metal for local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $159 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jonna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase scrap metals and bottles to sell. 

Jonna is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase scrap metals and bottles to sell. This will be her 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase scrap metals & bottles to sell

loans.name: Louise

texts.en: Louise owns a bar. She is 26 years old, married and has three children. Louise and her husband work together in the same business. Louise has been working in a bar for five years. Her loan will be used to add more beer and sodas to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy more beer to sell

loans.name: Ainura Jumagulova's Group

texts.en:
About 36 per cent of the population of Kyrgyzstan live in poverty, with average monthly wages ranging from $50 to $125. People living outside the major urban areas rely almost entirely upon herding and subsistence farming. Thanks to herding, the development of dairy businesses is being promoted.
Ainura J., 32, is the leader of this group. She and her husband devote their whole time to taking care of a couple of dairy cows. Every day, early in the morning, Ainura milks several liters and heads to a local market to sell the milk to customers. Ainura is very happy with her business, since her milk is of good quality and is always in high demand. The family started this business eight years ago with capital of 15,000 KGS. A monthly income of 9,000 KGS has helped them to raise three children, who are in school now.
Ainura has gathered this group of ambitious entrepreneurs in order to request a loan, which she is sure will be repaid by the established deadline. Ainura hopes to use her loan to purchase another dairy cow. She plans to spend her business returns on a good university education for her children.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Ilham

texts.ru:
Ilham M. 32 qoda. On jenat i imeyet odnoqo rebonka  kotoriy uchistay v 1 klasse. Ilham yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey lubimoy semyoy.
 
Ilham uje 6 let kak zanimayetsya  etim biznessom skotovodstva. Otec Ilhama toje bil skotovodom i  poetomu on s destva lubil jivotnix lubil smotret kak otec rabotayet i s podrostaniye nachal pomoqat otcu , seychas je on sam skotovod. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit korovi. Ilham izqotavlivayet yogurt , kefir i sir i moloka i prodayet ix u sebya doma, yeqo pokupateli v osnovnom yavlyayustay yeqo sosedi kotorim nravitsya yeqo produkti.
texts.en:
Ilham M. is thirty-two and married with one child in first grade.  He is an IDP [Internally Displaced Person] from the city of Fuzili and now lives with his beloved family in the Fuzili region.

For the past six years Ilham has been in the cattle business.  His father was a cattleman, so from childhood Ilham has loved animals and seeing how his father worked.  He started helping his father out when he was a teen, and now he's a cattle farmer himself.  Ilham needs 2000 AZN to buy cows.  He produces yogurt, kefir, cheese, and milk and sells them from home.  His clients mainly include his neighbors, who like his products.

loans.use: To buy cattle.

loans.name: Sairagul Sharsheeva's Group

texts.en:
Collective farming, called “kolkhozy”, was first introduced in the republics of the Soviet Union. Several farmers joined together in farming activities such as agriculture, cattle breeding and dairy production. This was a strategy for boosting the country’s production. Unfortunately, “kolkhozy” failed after the collapse of the Soviet Union, leaving hundreds of thousands of peasants managing the land on their own.
Sairagul S., 43, is the leader of this group. In Soviet times she used to be a dairymaid in a local “kolkhoz”. Like many others, she was left helpless after the collapse of Soviet Union. Having no education, but excellent skills in cattle breeding, she decided to continue this occupation. Three years ago, Sairagul ventured into the resale of cattle, which proved successful. Nowadays she spends most of her time taking care of cattle, but she also works as a salesperson in a nearby market on weekdays. Sairagul earns 6,000 KGS per month, but she still is unable to purchase some sheep for resale. In order to accomplish this goal she has applied for a loan from Kiva. Sairagul would like to spend her business returns on finishing the construction of her house, which she started two years ago.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Charles Mbugua

texts.en:
Charles, 32, is married to Susan Njeri, who is a farmer.  Together they have four children ages 10, 8, 6 and 3 years. He is a farmer and also operates a retail shop where he sells food items like sugar, cooking oil and other things. 

He has been in this business for 13 years and he finds it profitable, so that is why he wants to expand and invest more into farming activities to get more returns. This is the first loan he will be getting from KADET and he intends to rent a piece of land for farming. 

With the profits from this loan, Charles desires to develop another piece of land for other projects.

loans.use: to rent a piece of land for farming activities

loans.name: Inomjon

texts.en:
A. Inomjon is 33 years old and the father of two children who both attend the local school. His wife is a housekeeper. In order to earn a living, Inomjon owns a two-hectare field for cultivating wheat, tomatoes and corn. He also has a garden where he grows apricots. On his land, Inomjon is now unable to do any planting because he does not have enough money for seeds and fertilizer. In order to deal with this problem, he decided to ask for a loan of 7,500 TJS to buy necessary supplies. Inomjon sees this as an opportunity to obtain a better yield, which will improve his family's living conditions.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Ulugbek Tairov's Group

texts.en:
Jailoo is possibly the most exciting place to visit in Kyrgyzstan. In the Kyrgyz language it means a summer pasture high in the mountains, where shepherds move with their flocks of sheep, horses and cows.
Ulugbek T., 27, is a member of this group. Growing up in Jailoo, he kept the long-cherished family tradition of raising livestock including horses, sheep and cows. But Ulugbek also had ambitions to move to the city and start his own business. It’s been two years since he started driving a city cab in order to make a living. He also understood that selling cattle raised in the perfect conditions of Jailoo would provide a good source of income. Now Ulugbek spends his monthly income from cab driving on purchasing food for livestock that is taken care of by his parents. Ulugbek hopes to obtain a loan for buying additional livestock for resale. He believes his monthly profit will allow him to successfully repay the loan.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua T. has received a senior high education. She is a widow who prepares and sells kenkey (fermented corn dough) at Abura. She has been in this business for five years. Demand for kenkey is high and so Efua is requesting a loan to purchase extra bags of maize to process into kenkey, which she will sell to her customers. The additional profit she will make as a result of this loan will be reinvested back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase extra bags of maize to process into kenkey

loans.name: Inomjon

texts.en:
In the previous year’s growing season, Inomjon A. was diligent in his fertilizer- and pesticide-selling venture. In that season, Inomjon acquired adequate income and that income was used to improve his home and to save for the children’s education expenses. 

Because he spent the season diligently selling fertilizer, his own land is unprepared for planting. Currently, it is the rainy season, the  appropriate and suitable time for planting. Inomjon has taken the initiative to resume working on his land while selling fertilizer. He requires funds to purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizer. Inomjon is optimistic that his venture will be successful and all his efforts will improve the family’s welfare.

loans.name: Liberath

texts.en:
Liberath is 33 years old, married and has six children. Currently, four of her children are enrolled in school. 

Liberath sells clothes, which she has done for four years. Her husband also sells clothes. Besides that, she owns a milling machine, which also generates income. The machine is behind her in the picture. 

Liberath will use the loan to buy more clothes for both children and adults. With the new profits from her expanded business, Liberath plans to reinvest in the growth of her business and would like to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell
